Description: CHICAGO COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS FOR COVID RESPONSE AND RESILIENT COMMUNITIES - CHICAGO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH’S OVERARCHING GOAL IS TO ELIMINATE CHICAGO’S LIFE EXPECTANCY GAP FROM HEALTH DISPARITIES DUE TO RACIAL AND ETHNIC INEQUITIES.  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT CHICAGO’S RESPONSE TO COVID-19, CHRONIC DISEASE, AND HEALTHY LIVING BY INCREASING AND OPTIMIZING CHW TRAINING, TARGETING DEPLOYMENT OF CHWS TO HIGH IMPACT COMMUNITIES AND ENGAGING COMMUNITIES IN A FACILITATED CONVERSATIONS ON PRIORITIZING THEIR NEEDS TO STRENGTHEN THEIR RESILIENCE AGAINST HEALTH THREATS.  CHW INFRASTRUCTURE WILL BE DEVELOPED BY INTEGRATING CHWS FROM ACROSS CHICAGO'S EXISTING AND TRANSITIONING STRUCTURES TO A CENTRALIZED CHICAGO CHW COVID RESPONSE (CCR) PROGRAM FOR TRAINING, CAREER DEVELOPMENT, AND NETWORKING.  SUSTAINABILITY OF CHWS WILL BE EVALUATED THROUGH THE EVALUATION, PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT, AND QUALITY IMPROVEMENT FRAMEWORKS.

YUMA COUNTY CONNECT (CHWS, OUTREACH, NETWORKING, ENGAGEMENT, COLLABORATION AND TRAINING) - YUMA COUNTY COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKER (CHW) ROOTS DATE BACK TO 1987, AS PIONEERS IN THE ARIZONA COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKER MODEL THROUGH THE “COMIENZO SANO” (HEALTH START) PROGRAM.  THROUGH THE HEALTH START PROGRAM, CHWS HAVE PROVIDED EVIDENCE AS BEING FUNDAMENTAL IN REACHING DEMOGRAPHICALLY ISOLATED RURAL POPULATIONS, ESSENTIAL TO ESTABLISHING TRUST WITH THE HISPANIC/LATINO MIGRANT POPULATION, AND INDISPENSABLE WHEN REACHING COMMUNITIES WHO ARE IN NEED OF COMMUNITY RESOURCES.  YUMA COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICES DISTRICT (YCPHSD) PROPOSES TO IMPLEMENT COMPONENT B: IMPLEMENTATION READY. THROUGH THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY, WE PLAN TO SERVE THE HISPANIC/LATINO COMMUNITY, WHICH MAKES UP 69% OF THE COUNTY’S POPULATION.  THE PROPOSED CATCHMENT AREA FOR THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY IS YUMA COUNTY, ARIZONA. YUMA COUNTY IS A MULTI-CULTURAL BORDER COMMUNITY LOCATED IN THE OUTERMOST REGION OF SOUTHWEST ARIZONA NEIGHBORED BY THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA ON THE WEST AND THE COUNTRY OF MEXICO TO THE SOUTH. THE TOTAL POPULATION IS 209,468 AND SIXTY-NINE PERCENT (69%) IS OF HISPANIC/LATINO ORIGIN. HISPANIC/LATINOS ARE MORE AT RISK FOR POORER HEALTH OUTCOMES AND/OR DEATH DUE TO COVID-19 DUE HIGH THE PREVALENCE OF CHRONIC HEALTH CONDITIONS SUCH AS HEART DISEASE, CANCER, AND DIABETES.  ACCORDING TO THE STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES (ADHS) AS OF MAY 21, 2021 DATA, SHOWS THERE HAS BEEN 37,188 CONFIRMED CASES AND 838 DEATHS IN YUMA COUNTY SINCE THE ONSET OF THE PANDEMIC. FOR SEVERAL MONTHS, WHEN THE PANDEMIC REACHED OUR AREA YUMA COUNTY, AZ AND THE SOUTHERN BORDER STATE OF MEXICO, SONORA OUR COMMUNITIES WERE CONSIDERED “HOT SPOTS” DUE TO THEIR HIGH COVID-19 POSITIVITY RATE. RESIDENTS OF SOUTH YUMA COUNTY WERE PARTICULARLY CHALLENGED DUE TO LIMITED ENGLISH PROFICIENCY, CONGREGATE HOUSING SETTINGS FOR AGRICULTURAL WORKERS AND FAMILIES LIVING IN MULTI-GENERATIONAL HOMES. THE PURPOSE IN APPLYING FOR THE FUNDING OPPORTUNITY IS TO SERVE THE COMMUNITY AS A WHOLE WITH AN EMPHASIS TO SERVE HISPANIC MINORITIES, AGRICULTURAL FARM WORKERS, MIGRANT COMMUNITIES AND OTHER VULNERABLE POPULATIONS THROUGH THE EXPANDED REACH OF COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS TO OVERCOME COVID-19 ADVERSE OUTCOMES.  YCPHSD WILL ESTABLISH A LOCAL CHW COMMUNITY COALITION AIMED TO INFORM AND UNITE CHWS PROVIDING SERVICES AMONG THEIR RESPECTIVE CAPACITIES AND TO ESTABLISH MENTORSHIP OPPORTUNITIES FROM SEASONED CHWS.  THROUGH INVOLVEMENT OF STAKEHOLDERS, COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS, AND MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY, THE COALITION WILL ADDRESS THE OVERALL APPROACH TO TRAIN, DEPLOY, AND ENGAGE CHWS FOR COVID-19 RESPONSE, DECREASE HEALTH DISPARITIES AND INCREASE COMMUNITY RESILIENCY. TRAINING STRATEGIES WILL CONSIST OF LEARNING CORE FOUNDATION SKILLS TO SERVE AS A LIAISON/LINK/INTERMEDIARY BETWEEN HEALTH/SOCIAL SERVICES.  CHWS WILL UNDERGO CORE COMPETENCY TRAINING THROUGH AN ARIZONA APPROVED TRAINING PROGRAM.  CORE COMPETENCIES INCLUDE COMMUNICATION, RELATIONSHIP BUILDING, SERVICE COORDINATION, CAPACITY BUILDING, ADVOCACY, EDUCATION AND FACILITATION, ASSESSMENT, OUTREACH, PROFESSIONAL CONDUCT, AND KNOWLEDGE BASE.  CHWS WILL ALSO HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO BECOME VOLUNTARILY CERTIFIED AS A CHW PROFESSIONAL THROUGH THE LOCAL COMMUNITY COLLEGE ARIZONA WESTERN COLLEGE (AWC).  DURING THE 2018 LEGISLATIVE SESSION, ARIZONA STATE LEGISLATURE PASSED HB2324 VOLUNTARY CERTIFICATION FOR COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS THROUGH THE ARIZONA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES.  HB2324 WAS SIGNED BY GOVERNOR DOUG DUCEY ON MAY 18, 2021.  DEPLOY STRATEGIES WILL CONSIST OF ACTING AS AN EXTENSION OF PUBLIC HEALTH EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS AND IMMUNIZATION PROGRAMS SERVICES.  THROUGH THESE STRATEGIES, CHWS WILL PROVIDE MITIGATION EDUCATION, VACCINE EDUCATION AND RESOURCE DISSEMINATION AMONG THE LOCAL FARM WORKER COMMUNITY, HISPANIC/LATINO POPULATION AND UNDERSERVED YUMA COUNTY COMMUNITIES.  ENGAGE STRATEGIES WILL CONSIST OF LINKING THE TARGET POPULATION WI

COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS CAPACITY BUILDING FOR COVID RESPONSE AND RESILIENT COMMUNITIES

CHWS FOR COVID RESPONSE & RESILIENT COMMUNITIES - THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH’S OFFICE OF COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS PROPOSES MASSACHUSETTS CHWS FOR COVID RESPONSE AND RESILIENT COMMUNITIES (MA CCR). IN THIS INITIATIVE, TRAINED COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS (CHWS) WILL BUILD BRIDGES BETWEEN COMMUNITIES, HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS, AND LOCAL BOARDS OF HEALTH IN 9 COMMUNITIES WITH HIGH COVID-19 INFECTION AND MORTALITY RATES TO ADDRESS THE COVID-19-RELATED NEEDS OF COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND THE UNDERLYING INEQUITIES RESULTING IN UNEQUAL DISEASE BURDEN. TO DO THIS WORK, THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH (MDPH) IS APPLYING FOR BOTH COMPONENT B AND C. WITH THE AIM OF DECREASING THE IMPACT OF COVID-19 AND PROMOTING COMMUNITY RESILIENCE, COMPONENT B WILL INTEGRATE CHWS INTO PRIMARY CARE TO SUPPORT PATIENT-CENTERED CARE FOR THOSE AT-RISK FOR OR SUFFERING FROM COVID-19; AND COMPONENT C WILL DEPLOY CHWS IN LOCAL BOARDS OF HEALTH TO ENGAGE COMMUNITY RESIDENTS IN UPSTREAM PUBLIC HEALTH ACTIONS. WHILE EACH COMPONENT CAN STAND ALONE, COMBINED THEY CREATE A BROADER COMMUNITY IMPACT. IN MASSACHUSETTS, LIKE THE NATION, THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS HAD SIGNIFICANT POPULATION HEALTH IMPACTS INCLUDING ACUTE COVID-19-RELATED DISEASE, DISRUPTION OF NON-COVID CARE, INCREASED HEALTH-RELATED SOCIAL NEEDS, AND INCREASED MENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH NEEDS. THIS BURDEN HAS DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BLACK, INDIGENOUS, LATINX, AND PEOPLE OF COLOR. AS OF JULY 2020, BLACK NON-HISPANIC RESIDENTS REPRESENTED 7% OF THE MA POPULATION BUT DOUBLE THE PROPORTION OF COVID-19 CASES (14%); AND HISPANIC RESIDENTS REPRESENTED 12% OF THE MA POPULATION BUT MORE THAN TWICE THE PROPORTION OF CASES (29%). AGE-SPECIFIC DEATH RATES REVEAL THAT RESIDENTS WHO ARE HISPANIC, BLACK NON-HISPANIC, AND OTHER NON-HISPANIC HAVE HIGHER RATES OF DEATH IN EVERY AGE GROUP COMPARED TO RESIDENTS WHO ARE WHITE AND ASIAN NON-HISPANIC. CHWS ARE UNIQUELY EQUIPPED TO DEVELOP COMMUNITY RELATIONSHIPS AND BUILD TRUST WITH THE PEOPLE MOST IMPACTED BY COVID-19 DUE TO THEIR SHARED LIVED EXPERIENCE. DUE TO LONG-STANDING EXPERIENCE AND PARTNERSHIPS, MDPH CAN QUICKLY DEPLOY TRAINED CHWS IN PRIMARY CARE AND PUBLIC HEALTH SETTINGS TO ENGAGE THE INDIVIDUALS AND COMMUNITIES MOST IMPACTED BY THE PANDEMIC. FOR COMPONENT B, CHWS WILL WORK ALONGSIDE PRIMARY CARE PROVIDERS TO ADDRESS PATIENTS’ COVID-19 NEEDS WHILE ALSO FOCUSING ON REENGAGING PEOPLE IN PRIMARY CARE, HELPING NAVIGATE AND COORDINATE CARE, SUPPORT VACCINATION, AND ADDRESSING PATIENTS’ HEALTH-RELATED SOCIAL NEEDS. MA CCR CHWS WILL REACH 7,000 PATIENTS OVER 3 YEARS. FOR COMPONENT C, CHWS, WHO ARE EMPLOYED BY THE PRIMARY CARE SITE, WILL BE EMBEDDED IN THEIR LOCAL BOARDS OF HEALTH TO FOCUS ON ENGAGING THE COMMUNITY IN ASSESSING AND ADDRESSING THE UPSTREAM CAUSES OF POOR HEALTH. THE CHWS WILL WORK ALONGSIDE COMMUNITY COALITIONS TO ENSURE THE LOCAL COALITIONS CENTER THEIR WORK ON THE HEALTH EQUITY NEEDS OF THE GROUPS MOST IMPACTED BY COVID-19. MA CCR WILL MEANINGFULLY ENGAGE 1,500 RESIDENTS AND CHANGE AT LEAST 9 POLICIES RELATED TO HEALTH EQUITY. MUNICIPAL POLICY CHANGES WILL REACH THE ENTIRE COMMUNITY. THE PROPOSAL BUILDS ON MDPH’S EXTENSIVE EXPERIENCE AND NETWORK OF PARTNERS AND HAS STRONG SUPPORT FROM STATE AGENCY LEADERSHIP, ENSURING STRONG ALIGNMENT WITH THE STATE’S COVID-19 VACCINATION AND MITIGATION EFFORTS. MASSACHUSETTS HAS A LONG HISTORY OF PROMOTING AND SUPPORTING THE PROFESSION OF COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS (CHWS) AS AN IMPORTANT PUBLIC HEALTH WORKFORCE. IT WAS ONE OF THE FIRST STATES TO HAVE AN OFFICE OF CHWS IN ITS STATE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND THE FIRST STATE TO HAVE CREDENTIALING OF CHWS THROUGH A PROFESSIONAL BOARD CERTIFICATION PROCESS. FOR OVER 40 YEARS, MDPH HAS WORKED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH CHWS TO PROVIDE RESOURCES FOR CHW INITIATIVES, PROMOTE POLICIES THAT BUILD THE WORKFORCE, SUPPORT CORE COMPETENCY TRAINING OF CHWS, AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH AND HEALTH CARE ORGANIZATIONS EMPLOYING CHWS.

BUILDING RESILIENCE TO COVID-19 IN THE RMI THROUGH BETTER MENTAL HEALTH OUTREACH AND RESPONSE - MOHHS WILL BUILD THE CAPACITY OF THE MENTAL HEALTH CLINIC TO RESPOND TO COMMUNITY CONCERNS IN THE EVENT OF A COVID-19 INFECTION, AS WELL AS TO THE ESCALATING MENTAL HEALTH SERVICE NEEDS IN THE COUNTRY AS A RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THIS PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH A WELL-TRAINED CORPS OF COMMUNITY HEALTH OUTREACH WORKERS (CHWS) ABLE TO CONDUCT MENTAL HEALTH SCREENING, REFERRALS AND FOLLOW-UP SERVICES, COMMUNITY AWARENESS AND EDUCATION ABOUT MENTAL HEALTH AND OTHER HEALTH ISSUES, INCLUDING THE IMPORTANCE OF PROPER AND CONTINUED USE OF PPE AND GOOD HYGIENE PRACTICES, AND CONDUCT CONTACT TRACING IN THE EVENT OF A COVID-19 CASE IN THE RMI (AND FOR OTHER COMMUNICABLE DISEASES).

SAN DIEGO COUNTY COVID-19 COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKER PROGRAM - USING OUR REGIONAL LIVE WELL SAN DIEGO FRAMEWORK, THE COUNTY OF SAN DIEGO-COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKER PROGRAM (COSD-CHW PROGRAM) WILL ADDRESS DISPARITIES IN ACCESS TO COVID-19 INFORMATION AND SERVICES AMONG VULNERABLE POPULATIONS AND COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE CATCHMENT AREA OF SAN DIEGO COUNTY. THE COSD-CHW PROGRAM WILL ELEVATE THE WORK OF COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKERS (CHWS) THROUGH TRAINING, INTEGRATION AS MEMBERS OF MULTIDISCIPLINARY HEALTHCARE TEAMS, AND ENGAGEMENT IN WELL-COORDINATED OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES AIMED AT PRIORITY POPULATIONS. THE COSD-CHW PROGRAM IS SUBMITTED FOR FUNDING CONSIDERATION UNDER COMPONENT A.KEY PROJECT ACTIVITIES ARE:? EXPANSION OF AN EXISTING COLLABORATIVE, CONSISTING OF COUNTY CONTRACTORS, INTO A MORE INCLUSIVE CHW COMMUNITY COALITION THAT WILL BRING TOGETHER LOCAL CHW NETWORKS AND STAKEHOLDERS FROM OTHER SECTORS TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT MUTUALLY REINFORCED ACTIVITIES THAT ENGAGE CHWS TO ADDRESS HEALTH EQUITY ISSUES AND BUILD COMMUNITY RESILIENCE.? IMPLEMENTATION OF A REGIONAL COSD-CHW TRAINING PROGRAM TAILORED TO MEET THE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT NEEDS OF CHWS WHO ARE ON THE FRONTLINES OF THE COVID-19 RESPONSE.? DEPLOYMENT OF SEVEN NEW FULL TIME COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKER LIAISONS, TWO HIRED BY THE COUNTY WILL SUPPORT THE COSD-CHW TRAINING PROGRAM, AND FIVE HIRED BY A CONTRACTED PARTNER WILL COORDINATE OUTREACH, EDUCATION, AND COMMUNICATION AMONG CHWS.? CREATION OF A QUALIFIED CONTRACTOR LIST CONSISTING OF ORGANIZATIONS WITH CHWS WHO HAVE COMPLETED THE COSD-CHW PROGRAM TRAINING AND CAN ENGAGE IN COLLABORATIVE PROJECTS AIMED TO ACHIEVING EQUITABLE ACCESS TO RESOURCES, TESTING, VACCINATIONS, AND OTHER CLINICAL SERVICES AMONG PRIORITY POPULATIONS.OUTCOMES THAT WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH COSD-CHW PROGRAM ACTIVITIES DELIVERED WITHIN THE CATCHMENT AREA, AND MEASURED AS PART OF PROGRAM EVALUATION, ARE:? SHORT-TERM: (1) INCREASED SKILLS OF CHWS TO PROVIDE COVID-19 PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICES AND SUPPORT TO PRIORITY POPULATIONS, (2) INCR EASED CHW WORKFORCE DEPLOYED TO MANAGE THE SPREAD OF COVID-19, (3) INCREASED UTILIZATION OF COMMUNITY RESOURCES AND CLINIC SERVICES AMONG PRIORITY POPULATIONS.? INTERMEDIATE: (4) INCREASED REACH OF CHW-INFLUENCED MITIGATION EFFORTS AMONG PRIORITY POPULATIONS, (5) SUSTAINED PROMOTION AND INTEGRATION OF CHWS AS PART OF A COORDINATED COMMUNITY-CLINICAL WORKFORCE ADDRESSING HEALTH DISPARITIES AMONG PRIORITY POPULATIONS, (6) INCREASED PROVISION OF COMMUNITY RESOURCES AND CLINICAL SERVICES THAT AIM TO STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY RESILIENCE TO MITIGATE THE IMPACT OF COVID-19.? LONG TERM: (7) DECREASED IMPACT OF COVID-19 ON PRIORITY POPULATIONS AND WITHIN THE FOCUS AREAS AS A WHOLE, (8) INCREASED COMMUNITY RESILIENCE TO RESPOND TO COVID-19 AND FUTURE PUBLIC HEALTH EMERGENCIES.
BEFORE ALWAYS HAS AN AFTER: NAVIGATING BEYOND THE PANDEMIC
